By Jennifer Saba

NEW YORK, Jan 25 (Reuters Breakingviews) - Microsoft MSFT.O may soon find that its success (Full Story) will attract unwanted attention. The $2.2 trillion software company on Tuesday reported quarterly revenue that beat expectations. That extends the company's strong performance in recent years relative to its big technology peer group. After last week unveiling a deal to buy gaming outfit Activision Blizzard ATVI.O for $69 billion, Chief Executive Satya Nadella’s uncanny ability to avoid regulators' crosshairs may be running out.

The company behind the Windows operating system said sales for the quarter ending Dec. 31 jumped 20% year-over-year to nearly $52 billion. Microsoft’s cloud unit Azure, which has been gaining market share from Amazon.com AMZN.O, increased its sales 46%. Microsoft has scored on other fronts. Investors in the company's shares have done better in the past year than Meta Platforms FB.O, Amazon.com, Apple AAPL.O or Netflix NFLX.O. Among tech giants, only Google owner Alphabet’s GOOGL.O investors have done better.

Over the years, the Redmond, Washington company has earned a top spot in the acquisition league tables as well. Since 2013, it has totaled 235 deals, according to Refinitiv data. That's more than Amazon or Apple and triple the number of deals done by Facebook owner Meta, according to data from Refinitiv. Even so, it's Microsoft's rivals that have lately come in for the most attention from regulators and the U.S. Congress on antitrust grounds.

Further growth, including in the important cloud arena, could start to change that. But arguably the biggest trigger for Washington's competition watchdogs right now is mergers. Going after a large target (Full Story) like Activision, maker of “Call of Duty” and “Candy Crush," is bound to attract attention.

It's true that Microsoft, despite its size and presence in business computing, isn't clearly dominating one market. Google and Apple are more obviously gatekeepers for their respective mobile operating systems. Meta's Facebook and Instagram loom large over social media, while Jeff Bezos’ Amazon is a uniquely powerful force in e-commerce.

But the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission are pushing the traditional limits of merger antitrust thinking in a revamp (Full Story) that kicked off just last week. If Microsoft’s huge and increasing size isn't enough to trigger scrutiny, its effort to scoop up Activision surely will.

Follow @jennifersaba on Twitter

CONTEXT NEWS

- Microsoft on Jan. 25 reported revenue for the quarter ending Dec. 31 of $51.7 billion, up 20% year-over-year. The software company earned $18.8 billion, or $2.48 per share, compared with $15.5 billion, or $2.03 per share, during the same quarter the prior year.

- Microsoft said on Jan. 18 it plans to acquire Activision Blizzard for $95 per share in an all-cash transaction valued at $68.7 billion, inclusive of Activision’s net cash.


(Editing by Richard Beales and Sharon Lam)
